message:
[S08E01 SPOILERS AHEAD]
Game of thrones is back for one final time and monday saw everyones Whatsapp and Instagram stories flooded with the images and videos of the opening credits video. We present you with our breakdown for S08E01. There were a ton of references and theory reveals, so it is very possible that we missed some of them. Do let us know in the comments!

https://medium.com/@thescholarsavenue/game-of-thrones-s08e01-breakdown-e00340976a66

One of our alums from 2011 batch, Siddartha Khastgir is working as a Research Lead for Testing Driverless cars at WMG- University of Warwick, UK. He was awarded the prestigious Forbes 30 under 30 award last year. He has been involved in defining and executing WMG's long term research & development strategy for verification and validation of CAV technologies.
Prior to joining WMG, he had worked for FEV Motorentechnik GmbH, Germany.
He has recently given a TEDx talk on his research on Safety of Driverless cars.
We've attached the link

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KrOOXE3SW-A&feature=youtu.be

Artbeat | Spectra's Annual Art Exhibition

“The true work of art is but a shadow of the divine perfection.”

Spectra, IIT Kharagpur had organized Artbeat an annual art exhibition, providing an opportunity to the students to unveil their aesthetics and exhibit the fire of creativity in them. The theme proposed this year was ‘Other Worlds’, thus providing the students with an occasion to design and explore the avenues of their own utopian world. 

The central art piece was an origami art of ‘The Thousand Cranes’. The idea laid forward by Nastassja, Head of Spectra, is stimulated by the following spellbinding Japanese Folklore.
One thousand origami cranes is an assembly of one thousand paper held together by strings. An ancient Japanese legend professes that anyone who folds a thousand cranes will be granted a wish by the Gods.
Sadako Sasaki-A Japanese girl, who was exposed to radiation from the atomic bombing and was diagnosed with Leukemia started making cranes with the goal of making one thousand cranes while being bed-ridden. She made a total of fourteen hundred cranes before she passed away.

A painting named 'The Big Picture', also a creation by Spectra, depicts a contrast of adventure with peace. The idea was inspired by Abhishek,  Head of Spectra, in order to exemplify the theme, 'Other Worlds'.

An enthusiastic team from Spectra was available to explain the significance of various art pieces garnered by them, along with the drawing notebooks and canvasses of the members, comprising of some charming drawings. Various origami pieces were also on display, thus allowing the students to appreciate this archaic art of  Japanese paper folding.

We, at The Scholars’ Avenue, extend our heartfelt congratulations to Spectra, on their epic journey till now and wish them luck for their bright future ahead!

Note - Those of you who missed it today can still catch the exhibition tomorrow from 10am at Assembly Hall, Technology Students' Gymkhana.

IIT Kharagpur collaborates with Pullela Gopichand Badminton Academy:

In a welcome move, the institute will develop programmes which will focus on improving the mental well-being of the athletes with the aim of enhancing the quality of performance and resilience of the players of PGBA.

“Our objective is to provide more mind related training. The wider goal is to produce happy players,” said Prof. Chakrabarti. “Happiness is just one of the multi-layered platform that we are building. We are also setting up a Sports Academy (at IIT Kharagpur) that would promote collaborative research related to happiness in sports in general and badminton in particular, and science and technology in sports training.”

Read more at: https://www.hindustantimes.com/education/iit-kharagpur-collaborates-with-pullela-gopichand-badminton-academy-for-producing-happy-players/story-mEzU6IggfHPSSORebNfcZO.html

In light of recent events, we at The Scholars' Avenue thought it necessary to clarify our stance regarding the Gymkhana elections of 2019-20. To put it simply, we were and always will remain unbiased.

To start off, the comment posted from our page allegedly supporting Ninaad Lohakare was a slip up by one of the multiple managers of our page and the mistake was immediately rectified. As some of you may know, when a person's FB account is granted admin rights to an FB page, one may comment, like and share using either their personal account or the page's account. Unfortunately a novice to this game may unintentionally forget to switch to their personal account before posting about their personal views, which is what transpired here. The comment was immediately taken down once we realised the gaffe.

However, in the small window of time that they had, a certain group of people, who we shall refrain from naming, had taken a screenshot of the aforementioned comment to blow the situation out of proportion in favour of their VP candidate. Once again, to clarify, this post is not to malign any candidate, but rather, to clear any misconceptions regarding our stance. As far as we are concerned, the words of the accusers hold no credibility as their posts and the comments were so blatantly biased themselves.

Lastly, the differences in the critiques of the proposal regarding E-Rickshaws put forth by Shashank Mishra and Ninaad Lohakare were due to the fact that the team members assigned to writing the critique on the two candidates' proposals were different. This was not a result of their personal bias towards any candidate but simply resulted from a different way of seeing things. Granted, such asymmetries should have been removed by another round of reviews. However, we did not possess the luxury of time and manpower, as the edited proposals were handed over to us by the candidates only after the SOAPbox. Granted, this is no excuse and we would like to apologize to the student community for it. Further, a bias towards a candidate would imply that we gave favourable reviews of every proposal put forth by said candidate, which if one goes through our critiques, is clearly not the case.

Nevertheless, we do apologize if it appeared as though we were in favour of any candidate(s). We hope the student community can see through the agenda behind these allegations and come to the correct conclusion. 

As an independent media body, we at TSA put in a lot of effort to ensure that we put out quality content for our readers. It therefore goes without saying that we take all of our posts- and your criticism of them-very seriously. We assure our readers that this blunder was a one-off, and we are the same TSA whose opinions you used to trust and whose only affiliation was, and remains, to the KGP community.

General Secretaries, Technology: Yogesh Kanik, Ninad Sanjay Patil
General Secretaries, Social and Cultural: Soumya Patel, Ayushi Thakur
General Secretaries, Sports and Games: Aditya Singhania, Mayank Manjeara

Event updates | MS PhD panel discussion

The panel shall consist of students who obtained offers from various top colleges around the world who shall be discussing how they obtained their offers and shall clear out doubts you have regarding same.

Venue: V3 
Time: 6:30pm, 27th of March, 2019.

A sudden change in the requirements for a VP candidate caused two aspiring candidates to be no longer eligible for the post. One of them held a nominated post under Gymkhana. Until last year those who held an elected post under TSG apart from that of the secretary, are not allowed to stand for an election for the second time. The rule did not state anything about nominated posts. Until last year that is.  The other candidate had an issue with another change in rules regarding his academic track. 

Our sister media body Awaaz, IIT Kharagpur covers this story in greater detail in the attached link below.

https://medium.com/@awaazofiitkgp/bending-the-election-rules-the-abuse-of-power-dd905cdba273?sk=8d7bc3e2e5ef604402ced6ea0ccb878b&fbclid=IwAR3dSEowLzoZVoR4ldEv3lxgKMzjusgnNj3gztGyy897KmfDV4s4Woi-WOQ

“While some may see them as crazy, we see genius, because the people who are crazy enough to think they can transform the world are the ones who do.”

Team Kart, a gang of ingenious geeks who probe into the practical side of automotive engineering, conducted a bay visit to make the students of the institute cognizant of the stellar work done by this officially sponsored research project under Sponsored Research and Industrial Consultancy Cell and the Department of Mechanical Engineering, IIT Kharagpur. A recent culmination of 
their extensive efforts has taken the form of their latest project, K4, the sixth creation of Team KART.

The bay visit was particularly conducted to showcase their latest endeavour. Commencing from scratch, Team KART first simulates a new project before constructing a CAD model of the project. The created model is then subjected to analysis validations before a blueprint is ready to be given for manufacturing. Team KART also specializes in in-house manufacturing. The fuel tank, chassis structures, pedal box and rockers are solely manufactured by Team KART itself.

The recently concluded project of K4 focusses primarily to refine and enhance speed and drivers’ safety. To facilitate attainment of high speed, it utilises light and durable body of carbon fibre, in addition to 13-inch untreated race tyres and limited slip-type differentials and eccentric differential mounts which facilitates ease of use and reduces the weight. Besides this, Team KART has also conceptualized and manufactured a contraption of its own to calculate and digitally display engine RPM and temperature of the engine. Ultimately, safety does not come with luck, it has to be prepared. K4 is deemed safe for a driver and has gone through The Mechanical Endurance Test adjudging the safety guidelines of the project. K4 endured the technical scrutiny, emerging as one of the sixteen teams to effectively clear three rounds of mechanical inspection test, tilt test and noise test out of participation of 70 teams.
 
The Bay Visit facilitated students to know more about this vibrant research group, appreciate their sincere and stoic efforts, and interact with the team, which, since its inception in 2008, has persevered in the field of automotive engineering. Students, bubbling with enthusiasm, were explained the CAD model of K4, working of the project and simulations by an equally enthusiastic team. K4 had also participated in Formula Bharat 2019 at Coimbatore hosted by Mobility Engineering Consortium Pvt. Ltd.

We at The Scholars' Avenue extend our heartfelt congratulations to Team Kart on their journey till now and wish them luck for their bright future ahead!

The created model is then subjected to analysis validations before a blueprint is ready to be given for manufacturing. Team KART also specializes in in-house manufacturing. The fuel tank, chassis structures, pedal box and rockers are solely manufactured by Team KART itself.

The recently concluded project of K4 focusses primarily to refine and enhance speed and drivers’ safety. To facilitate attainment of high speed, it utilises light and durable body of carbon fibre, in addition to 13-inch untreated race tyres and limited slip-type differentials and eccentric differential mounts which facilitates ease of use and reduces the weight. Besides this, Team KART has also conceptualized and manufactured a contraption of its own to calculate and digitally display engine RPM and temperature of the engine. Ultimately, safety does not come with luck, it has to be prepared. K4 is deemed safe for a driver and has gone through The Mechanical Endurance Test adjudging the safety guidelines of the project. K4 endured the technical scrutiny, emerging as one of the sixteen teams to effectively clear three rounds of mechanical inspection test, tilt test and noise test out of participation of 70 teams.
 
The Bay Visit facilitated students to know more about this vibrant research group, appreciate their sincere and stoic efforts, and interact with the team, which, since its inception in 2008, has persevered in the field of automotive engineering. Students, bubbling with enthusiasm, were explained the CAD model of K4, working of the project and simulations by an equally enthusiastic team. K4 had also participated in Formula Bharat 2019 at Coimbatore hosted by Mobility Engineering Consortium Pvt. Ltd.

We at The Scholars' Avenue extend our heartfelt congratulations to Team Kart on their journey till now and wish them luck for their bright future ahead!

MachPrinciple.com launches in India in February 2019  

In 2015, there were more than 150,000 research papers published per month, more than 50% papers were never read except by the author, editor and the referee, and more than 90% papers were never cited. According to statistics presented in Nature, about 1,620,731 papers were published in 2018 only in different science Journals. Enter MachPrinciple.

MachPrinciple is a LinkedIn-like professional network that allows general public and academicians to connect with each other, find latest discoveries in the field of their interest, find upcoming conferences, give feedbacks about different educational institutes etc. It launches with a bold promise that it will change the way research is carried out across the world. Its powerful features will allow the academic community to interact with common people, exchange knowledge and improve the visibility of their research works.  

MachPrinciple is founded by Dr Santanu Das, an astrophysicist at UW Madison and alumni IIT Kharagpur (batch of 2009). “Developing a new research technique takes years of painstaking and frustrating research which makes it all the more important to spread the knowledge of discovery of such new techniques. The most favourable way for this is publishing papers in deemed academic journals or presenting it in a conference. However, with the number of research papers increasing dramatically, the research space is fast getting cluttered to the point that it is humanly impossible for a scientist to read and understand any research outside their own discipline. The inter-disciplinary applications, as a result, are reduced to of chances and delays.” says Das. He believes that a social media platform like MachPrinciple can help in promoting research to scientists of other disciplines and even general audiences because “People love to hear about the latest discoveries in academia.”  

While he acknowledges that different social networking sites like ResearchGate and Academia. edu have done a wonderful job over the last decade in promoting open access to scientific work, he claims that by opening academic knowledge to all stakeholders - students, professors and researchers - MachPrinciple is the next step in the process. The Scholars’ Avenue appeals to the student and professor community to review the site and voice their concerns and questions. Feel free to contact Dr Santanu Das at sanjone[at]gmail[dot]com for better clarity.

Stay tuned for more.

Amazon Web Services Free Credits
In what comes as a welcome move, Amazon Web Services (AWS) will be providing free cloud credits of up to $75 for students and $150 for faculty for academic and research endeavours.
This initiative is aimed at facilitating teaching, class and lab assignments, course Projects, thesis related work, masters and PhD research, student and institute driven Initiatives etc. This is being coordinated through the Centre for Artificial Intelligence.
A detailed procedure regarding registration for the credits will be made public soon. 
Several training programmes, challenge problems and competitions have been developed around this to spread awareness and help people gain expertise.
The Institute hopes that this will help students and faculty alike to get started with cloud computational support for academic and research activities. Other facilities like Peta-flop Supercomputing and more cloud computing support are expected to come up soon.
We, at The Scholars' Avenue, appreciate the effort from the Institute to foster world-class AI facilities and expect the student fraternity to make the best use of the same.

Aerial Robotics Lab, IIT Kharagpur has invited a special guest, an eminent scientist Shreyansh Daftry to share some interesting insights about Intelligent Robotics for space exploration and some other ongoing NASA projects. He is a researcher at Jet propulsion Laboratory, NASA and will be giving a talk about the world of Aerial Robotics and Space Technologies. He received his M.S. degree in Robotics from the School of Computer Science, Carnegie Mellon University, USA. He pioneers in several fields including Computer Vision, Machine Learning and Space Robotics and has placed an integral part in developing autonomous robots for space exploration. 

Also do be present there to find out what happens in Aerial Robotics Kharagpur!

The Autonomous Ground Vehicle (AGV) group is a student-run research group at IIT Kharagpur, aspiring to build India's first fully autonomous ground vehicle. The group focuses on developing autonomous systems and is involved in research related to computer vision, machine learning, planning, embedded sensors and mechanical design. They regularly publish research papers at top conferences and have done very well in international robotics competitions.
 
Autonomous Ground Vehicle Research Group are hosting their Introduction Seminar on 29th January at 6:30PM, Kalidas Auditorium. Be present there to know more!

Autonomous Ground Vehicle Research Group are hosting their Introduction Seminar on 29th January at 6:30PM, Kalidas Auditorium. Be present there to know more!

The Autonomous Ground Vehicle (AGV) group is a student-run research group at IIT Kharagpur, aspiring to build India's first fully autonomous ground vehicle. The group focuses on developing autonomous systems and is involved in research related to computer vision, machine learning, planning, embedded sensors and mechanical design. They regularly publish research papers at top conferences and have done very well in international robotics competitions.
 
Autonomous Ground Vehicle Research Group are hosting their Introduction Seminar on 29th January at 6:30PM, Kalidas Auditorium. Be present there to know more!

17th to 20th January saw three teams from IIT Kharagpue break in the 12th NUJS Parliamentary Debate, Kolkata - one of the leading Parliamentary Debating Competitions of the country. More than 50 teams across India and from abroad participate in this tournament, host to some of the world's best speakers and adjudicators.

SEMIFINALS:
After besting veteran teams comprising professional debaters from India and abroad, the team of Rohit Sar, Rohit Roy, and Subhrajit Chowdhury lost to the team that would later go on to claim the final victory at the tournament. This team had also won Gold in the Inter-IIT Cultural Meet at the end of 2018.

QUARTERFINALS:
The team of Suyash Ratna Tripathi, David Vishal, and Vignesh Viswanathan journeyed to the quarterfinals riding on the shoulders of their ironclad cases.

OCTAFINALS:
The team of Chandar Siddarth, Rohan Khilnani, and Sutirtha Roy, with their spectacular team dynamics, fought through to the octafinals where they lost in a tough battle against the team that came out on top in the tabs.

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the debaters on their brilliant performance!

message:
KGP has had a history of producing eloquent speakers and flamboyant debaters. From a #Teen_Baar_Lagatar Gold in Parliamentary Debate, Inter IIT Cultural Meet to numerous tournaments across India, KGP DebSoc is one of the best in the Eastern Debating Circuit of India.
Last weekend, i.e, 17th to 20th January 2019, three KGP teams broke into 12th NUJS Parliamentary Debate, Kolkata which is one of the best Parliamentary Debating Competition in India. More than 50 teams from India and abroad participate in this tournament that hosts some of the world's best speakers and adjudicators.
SEMIFINALS.
After defeating strong teams of professional debaters of India and abroad, Rohit Sar, Rohit Roy, and Subhrajit Chowdhury lost to the winners of this year's NUJS PD. This team had also won Gold in Inter-IIT Cultural Meet this year.
QUARTERFINALS.
Suyash Ratna Tripathi, David Vishal, and Vignesh Viswanathan marked their remarkable reach to quarters on the grounds of strong cases.
OCTAFINALS.
Chandar Siddarth, Rohan Khilnani, and Sutirtha Roy, with their spectacular team dynamics, took their team to octas and lost in a tough fight against the top team on tabs.
The Scholars' Avenue wishes them amazing debating careers ahead!

Nihilanth 2019 | Champions
The People's Socialist Quiz Committee of the Proletarian Republic of KGP or IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club as it is popularly known has turned winning medals into a habit! This time they have made IIT Kharagpur proud as they have been declared champions in Nihilanth 2019, an Inter IIT-IIM quiz fest. 
Standings:
1st Place: IIT Kharagpur with 53 points
2nd Place: IIT Bombay with 49 points
3rd Place: IIT Madras with 46 points
We extend our hearty congratulations to the victors on their well-deserved victory and wish that this dream run for the club lasts long.
Tag yourselves in the picture!
story: The Scholars' Avenue is with Saswata Banerjee and 13 others.

message:
Peer Assisted Learning (PAL)
A student mentorship program, named Peer Assistant Learning (PAL), was flagged off under the aegis of the office of the Dean UG, IIT Kharagpur with the help of the UG Council. 
This programme aims to help students (academically) in subjects that generally a lot of students fail to perform well in. This program is going to be implemented for the first time in the Spring 2019 session with nine subjects shortlisted. Senior undergraduate students who have scored well in a particular subject shall tutor the current batches in that particular subject for a certain fixed period of time in return for an honorarium and certification from the office of Dean, UGS.
Third, fourth and fifth year UG students are requested to apply for the tutorship at the following link: https://goo.gl/forms/awsN2NiJdSzFNiqC3 
For complete details regarding the initiative, refer to the Full Document at: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1MohTiKfFICxRI49jaAhp7vi7arZPj7Sw/view
The last Date for application submission is 22nd January, 2019 5pm.
We appreciate the efforts made by UG council, Dean UG and everybody else responsible for this initiative and request active performance from 3rd, 4th and 5th year students to make this program a success.
The UG Council is very open to suggestions and improvements to the current initiative(s) kindly reach out to them at bandikrushi@gmail.com for the same.

Inter IIT Sports | Chess
We are happy to report that IIT Kharagpur has bagged silver in the ongoing Inter IIT Sports meet.
The team had won five matches and drawn two until a tiebreaker was played against IIT Bombay, which resulted in a victory for the team from Bombay.
The KGP team consisted of Gajendra Kumar, Koustav Chakraborty, Sankalp Baliarsingh, Desai Saurabh, Hemanth Kumar and Prithwi Sinha.
The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the chess contingent on their deserved victory!
#InterIIT2018 #Go_For_Gold
Picture Credits: IIT KGP Sports

The Scholars' Avenue shared Ambar - IIT Kharagpur's post. Hi! We are trying to bring about a healthy discourse on the systemic sexual harassment within our campus. Realising how deeply this problem affects some of our friends on campus will be a significant step towards sensitisation. Let's all come together and put forward our honest experiences. Please refrain from using any names; both, of yourself and the perpetrator's. https://goo.gl/forms/tNIynvINAXYL4MMl1

Please refrain from using any names; both, of yourself and the perpetrator's. https://goo.gl/forms/tNIynvINAXYL4MMl1

Agnext is offering a winter internship this December with exciting opportunities in the field of Computer vision, AI, IOT, Cloud Computing (Google Cloud/AWS), Web / Android Applications, Business Development and Case-studies. All projects are linked with commercial products, being developed in collaboration with Govt and Corporate giants.  Apart from the impressive stipend, you get to patent your work, depending upon your efforts. 

Check out the form below to register!

https://docs.google.com/forms/d/e/1FAIpQLSfTM_jSKBQgObbQbeki02LpE0O9sUOdKwp_0UPRkrcMh0K_4A/viewform

One semester is over and so is half the tenure of our representatives at the Gymkhana. Here's the time to put the democracy at play and ask what you want to know.

Is there any specific problem that you feel needs to be accounted for?
Do you think that your representatives aren't doing their jobs well?
Any promises that were read out at SOPs and then completely forgotten?

Fill in the form and ask your questions anonymously.
The Scholars' Avenue will get you the answers you deserve to know.
Spread the news and start asking. Each of your questions matters to make a more transparent system.
Here are the proposals-
https://web.scholarsavenue.org/tagged/kgp-elections

https://goo.gl/forms/jjCRISGstyCi9YdB2

The Tower Research Capital India are providing scholarships based on merit to second and third year undergraduates from the department of Computer Science and Engineering, Electronics and Electrical Communications Engineering, and Maths and Computing in association with International Relations Cell, IIT Kharagpur.

The scholarship covers up to 2 Lakhs towards tuition fees and other charges and grants up to 20K additional books grant. It is entirely merit based and requires one to have a minimum CG of 8.5. Visit the below link to know more.

https://international.iitkgp.ac.in/scholarships/TRC/?fbclid=IwAR2RWEAcjqGxqLRswLu8PPHTNgnq1b6T4wtuSwMgUnVz44Z1kSrsJMmi5TU

American comic book writer, creator of Spiderman, and the man whose presence was awaited for in every single Marvel movie, Stan Lee, passed away at an age of 95. 

He created a comic revolution which  extended beyond the characters and storylines to the way in which comic books engaged the readership and built a sense of community between fans and creators. 

A good heart has stopped beating, a good soul ascended to heaven, or maybe to infinity and beyond. Excelsior.

The Scholars' Avenue met up with Mr. S. S. Jha, Head of The Security Section to inquire about the various measures taken by his team to ensure safe dwelling in the campus.
Here are the few things about the security section and facilities that are available and that you might have missed.

>How watched are we?
CCTV cameras have been already installed at the gates and the cross sections of campus. The footages will be held with the security section and will be used in cases of thefts and complaints regarding specific incidents. After installations, it has become easier to track down incidents of stolen cycles and it has empowered the security section to direct efforts in the proper direction. Halls and other common areas have already equipped with these cameras and the process of installing more is still going on. So if you're planning on something notorious, now is not the right time.

>What about the vehicle filled KGP? 
Almost got crushed by some random speeding car on campus? Serious planning is going on for vehicle tracking and regulating in the campus. Passes are being issued to the vehicle that does not belong to residents of the campus and the validity is reduced to 3 months. Without renewal of the pass, outsiders wouldn't be let in. Given the CCTVs at gates, trespassers better stick to it.

>What if I'm in an emergency? How do I get help?
In what we felt like one of the most useful initiative, The Security Section has formed a Quick Relief Team (QRTs). The security professionals will be strolling the campus all the time to get to you within a few minutes of your call for help.
Save the numbers of QRTs- 03222-281002, 03222-281003

>Are there any special provisions for Women's Safety?
Not yet but on the way. Special QRTs will be made for the safety of girls in the campus. This would imply access to security in girls halls 24*7. This will also mean that female student will be more free and comfortable to contact the security in times of need. The women security professionals will be specially trained to cater to the female population of the campus.

>I don't feel safe due to some individuals on campus. Can I have access to security?
The Security Section Head told us that they consider every case individualistically and try to reach out to students in whatever ways possible. If any student believes that his security is threatened by anyone, he/she can report it to the security section and they will provide whatever assistance necessary if the threat is legitimate.

The Scholars' Avenue will stay in touch with The Security Section to convey the needs of the student community and know about the status of various projects that they have taken up.
We'll be glad to take up suggestions from you.

The Scholars' Avenue shared Code Club, IIT Kharagpur's post. Code Club, IIT Kharagpur would like to extend their hearty congratulations to the teams who have qualified for the ACM-ICPC Onsite Finals Amritapuri-Coimbatore Region : 1.) demossers ( Surya Addanki, Aravind Kollipara and Satish Kumar Reddy Karri ) - Overall Rank 49 2.) power_rangers ( Rakesh Malviya, Deepak Yadav and Jyoti Agrawal ) - Overall Rank 80 3.) VeniVidiVici ( Arpit Jain, Piyush Rathi and Saurav Ray ) - Overall Rank 83 4.) DecisionTree ( Vishal Garimella, Aurghya Maiti and Tyss Santosh ) - Overall Rank 116 5.) lachha paratha ( Srinidhi Bhat, Harsha Vardhan Ponnada and Srikanth Palem ) - Overall Rank 127 6.) mass_bunk ( Ayush Bansal , Mayank Bhushan and Ranjith Kumar ) - Overall Rank 134 7.) icepiceboys ( Rahul Das, Himanshu Mundhra and Aditya Anand ) - Overall Rank 139 8.) TheBigBug ( Pratik Tibrewal, Vishal Mishra and Param Mangal ) - Overall Rank 160 9.) premieressai ( Prathamesh Chavan, Harsha Sai Reddy and Shekar Reddy Yeredla ) - Overall Rank 204 10.) unsigned_Int_elligence ( Sahil Singh , Robin Babu Padamadan and Rajat Kumar Jenamani ) - Overall Rank 208 11.) Dummy_C0d0rs ( Mandar Kakade, Sourav Khemka and Manoj Preveen ) - Overall Rank 267 12.) BitfulNoseBytes ( Krithick Santhoshn, Anjaneya Praharaj and Shivam Saxena ) - Overall Rank 293 13.) The Missing Semicolon ( Poojitha Maheshappa, Pranit Chawla and Kavish Gupta ) - Overall Rank 315 14.) triCoder - Overall Rank 315 15.) WhitePowder ( Ayush Mahajan , Saurabh Agarwal and Omar Eqbal ) - Overall Rank 431 We wish them luck and hope they make it to the World Finals!!

message: Hey guys! Next up is Keerthana, who went on to pursue an MS in Robotics after majoring in Mechanical Engineering.

Gangireddy Hanimi Reddy, second-year postgraduate student evidently committed suicide yesterday (24th Oct) in his room. The 24-year-old was found hanging from the ceiling fan by security guards around 7 PM. His body was bent over on a table with a rope hanging his neck from the ceiling. There was a delay before the door was struck down. The ambulance arrived at the scene with doctors and Reddy was confirmed dead by the doctors. Dean of Student Affairs, Hall Wardens, Vice President also arrived soon enough to look into the matter. His body was taken to the hospital for Autopsy.

G H Reddy, son of Gangireddy Venkata Reddy, hailed from Andhra Pradesh. He took admission in IIT Kharagpur in 2017 and was a boarder of MMM Hall since. The Hall community is still recovering from the shock of this news. Further investigation about this matter is going on.

As sad as it might be, this certainly questions amiability of counselling center and several other Institute Wellness drives that started last year.

We are happy to inform you that a two-day workshop will be jointly organized by IISE Student Chapter #660 and E-Business Centre of Excellence, IIT Kharagpur at the department of Industrial and  Systems Engineering, during October 27-28, 2018. The workshop will be on "Application of Data analytics and Machine learning using Python".

The seats are limited (55 only), so registration will be provided on the basis of First Come First Serve. The participants from other departments of IIT Kharagpur are welcome to join this workshop. To register and know more details, please follow the link given below:

https://drive.google.com/file/d/1McxZ3QI-XkNeKnyulUIbvL9SZatQi6bT/view

Jugaad is probably one of the most casually used words, especially finding its way into conversations between students and most frequently thrown around before submissions and deadlines. It incorporates an ad-hoc approach meant to solve problems with immediate efficacy and represents innovative, albeit sometimes ephemeral, capabilities, but a deeper truth underlying this mentality suggests a darker side to it. We as Indians are famously known for our prowess in jugaad and it’s no coincidence that our progress towards development is encumbered with an increasing pace of problems piling up and a mismatch in the rate of sustainable solutions being offered. Recent times have seen some instrumental shifts in the momentum of our progress, but hidden to the collective eye is a sea of untapped potential that can possibly accelerate the same. Delineating this stand and carefully drawing the lines between frugality and jugaad, words that are often confused as the same, two of our distinguished alumni Prof. Aloke Kumar (2005|DD|MF+Industrial|RP), currently an Assistant Professor at IISC Bangalore, and Prof. Ranajay Ghosh (2004|B.Tech|ME|RP), currently an Assistant Professor at the University of Central Florida, explore this issue with prominent examples in an article they authored recently. 

Disclaimer: The views and opinions presented by the authors in the article are theirs alone and do not necessarily reflect the same of The Scholar’s Avenue. 

https://thedrashta.blogspot.com/2018/07/jugaadism-infantile-disorder.html

Interested people can head to : https://github.com/IEEEKeralaSection/rescuekerala

As most are already aware, Kerala is facing its worst flood since 1924. The death toll has risen to 186, Red Alert has been sounded in 12 out of the 14 districts and 10 districts have been severely affected. Nearly Ten thousand people have been shifted to rehabilitation camps. The battle we are fighting is manifold.

Therefore, the TechKeralites (Society of Kerala Staff and students) group at IIT Kharagpur is organizing a Relief Fund Collection for the Kerala CM Distress Relief Fund. We request you to contribute generously to the affected people of the state. We would also appreciate if you could spread or share this message with others.

We thank all the people who have extended love and support in this time of devastation.

Please find the details of the account to which the financial support can be transferred.

In this episode, he gets ranting about the measures, which included programs like the Reach out Hour and Induction Programme among others, taken up by the institute to help people combat psychological issues like depression, loneliness and anxiety.

Click the link below to find out what it is that bugs him about this.

message:
KGP Graph Theory | Season 3 | Episode 1

Of all forms of diversities, body-weight(or rather body-mass) remains one observable trait which, despite being the most concerning in this post-millennial world, still is flexible as to how sensibly it has established itself to the mess food, cycling frequencies, festival interventions and the rickety roads in the campus of IIT KGP. Here is a testimonial for the same, as The Scholars' Avenue presents you all the first episode of Graph Theory, this semester - THE WEIGHING MACHINE.

Does it relate to you, or a friend of yours? If yes, how well does it? Let us know in the discussion below. :)

It has come to light that stricter network restrictions have been applied to IIT Kharagpur’s internet, the most prominent of these being the enabling of “Restricted Mode” on Youtube. Restricted Mode not only prevents any and all videos that may be deemed explicit or mature from being viewed, but also disables comments on all youtube videos. This has had the probably unintended consequence of removing many popular music videos, which have been regrettably deemed “inappropriate” for a demographic aged 18- 23. A number of other websites, such as movie streaming site fmovies and social media platform 9gag have also been blocked. 

We at Scholars’ Avenue are making efforts to get more concrete information from official sources, since no communication has taken place with the student body.

Day 2 | Assimilation Programme 

The Day-2 of the Central Events of the Assimilation Programme 2018 took place today at the Netaji Auditorium. Due to a staggering turnout of less than 10%, the event had to be postponed by at least half an hour, when the quorum was finally met. The first session, "Motivational Lecture-II" had Dr Era Dutta, a consultant, neuropsychiatrist, therapist, and a life coach from Kolkata involving the students in an interactive talk about Success and Depression. With statistics and examples, the students explored the pervasive traits of depression, its correspondence with success and its cure, the happiness. "Happiness is the whole pie and we are focusing only on success which is just a small chunk. Why not focus on the whole pie?", she said. The session thus ended with her advice to this post-millennial audience, which was to keep chanting a happiness mantra, "Today was a good day."
 
By 7:15, the strength has already increased to about 300 for the latter event of the day, "Carrer Workshop-2" conducted by the External Relations Cell and the CDC. In continuation to the CV filling workshop of last week, this session involved an insight into various opportunities available for an undergraduate student at IIT Kharagpur. Four sectors viz., Higher Studies, Public Sector, Corporate Sector, and Entrepreneurship sector were discussed. Students were given a rough outline of how it is to choose one of them and implement accordingly a set of plans, internships to do and courses to undertake. At around quarter past eight, the day ended and as anticipated by most of the people, no attendance was taken.

message:
NOTICE FROM THE ERP TEAM
------------------------------------------------
Dear Students,

It has come to our notice that several phishing mail or whatsapp messages are in circulation on campus. It may ask you to enter the ERP login credentials or your personal details. Please do not provide any information on these malicious sites. These sites/software/browser extensions are possibly capturing your secret data, for misuse, which you should not share/disclose with anybody.

Before entering the ERP login credentials, please make sure that you are browsing the valid site (https://erp.iitkgp.ac.in/). In addition, ERP is also in process of implementing a mobile app (IIT KGP ERP) which may ask for the ERP login credentials. It's always recommended to change your ERP login credentials at regular intervals.

Thanks,

ERP Team
IIT Kharagpur

Machine Learning and Image Processing Workshop: AgNext (3rd to 10th August)

AgNext is conducting a one-week workshop for 20 selected candidates. Post the workshop, selected students would be invited for the AgNext Fellowship through which they can participate in the development of interesting and impactful products involving ML/AI/IP in areas like IOT, Robotics, Automation, Drone and Satellite Imaging,  Sensor Data processing and Security.  They seek passionate and enthusiastic members who are eager to learn and contribute to socially impactful technological products.

Find the registration link below!

https://goo.gl/forms/PP2rLzE9krBtyezl1

Post the workshop, selected students would be invited for the AgNext Fellowship through which they can participate in the development of interesting and impactful products involving ML/AI/IP in areas like IOT, Robotics, Automation, Drone and Satellite Imaging,  Sensor Data processing and Security.  They seek passionate and enthusiastic members who are eager to learn and contribute to socially impactful technological products.

VERY IMPORTANT NOTICE FROM THE DEAN OF STUDENT AFFAIRS (DOSA)
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Dear Students,

There is a threat of an imminent strike by the outsourced mess workers of some of the halls where contractual employees are working. They may be supported by other contractual workers of the halls too. Already there is stoppage of work by some of these workers in the messes. The Institute administration is trying to handle the issue with the help of the district administration.

At this point we need cooperation from all students to overcome this situation. Arrangements are being made to have restricted cooking. The breakfast may be in packed form. The lunch and dinner may be cooked with the help of regular mess employees who will work extra time after completing the work in their respective halls. The campus community may also help in providing the food in halls. Institute administration is working out strategies to face the situation.

It is imperative that all the regular activities of the institute such as classes, labs, tests, co-curricular and extra-curricular will continue as usual. The students are advised not to enter into any kind of altercation with the employees. It is important that the student community shows its resilience in the face of adversity. Hall presidents and other hall council members will provide necessary guidance in the matter. The student leaders and the Institute authorities may be approached anytime in case of any difficulty related to this.

Day 1 | Phase 2 | Assimilation Programme

The second phase of Day 1 of the Assimilation Programme 2018 had the ExR cell and the SWG taking over the stage of Kalidas Auditorium to conduct some interesting and useful workshops. Despite a low turnover, the programme began only a little off-scheduled at 6:20 in the evening.

The session started with Somil Gupta and Raghav Jalan of the External Relations Cell conducting a workshop on CV-building. All the key essentials of a CV and a cover letter were discussed here. There was a brief overview of the format, signature and some useful browser extensions while sending a mail, and the protocol to be followed while taking telephonic and personal interviews. It was 7:40 by the time the workshop ended. Despite SWG's portents of upcoming attendance-check, almost half of the already fewer students started leaving for their hostels. 

The session however continued with Abhrajit Saha and Ruchin Raj of the Institute Wellness Group elaborating on the establishment and ideals of IWG. There was then, a display of around 10 popular KGP themed memes. This was shortly followed by a short picture story of a lonely KGP boy facing mental stigma and his prospects of living in the presence and absence of friends. The anecdote then moved on to elucidate the importance and reliability of the Counselling Centre. Then, there was an introduction to YourDOST and a funny demonstration on the working of its interface through a fake YourDOST id "Spidy69." When the counsellor messaged "Hey, can I call you Spidy?", the user replied, "Where is the 69?." Abrajit even said, "Make use of it. Afterall, the institute pays them 13.5 lakh a year." 

With this, the session ended and no attendance was taken.
story: The Scholars' Avenue added 3 new photos.

message:
Assimilation Program | Day 1

TL;DR Attendance was taken.

The first scheduled program of Assimilation program started with Krushi Bandi addressing the gathering about what Assimilation program was. He mentioned that the Assimilation Program was completely different from OP in a sense that all the activities would be monitored and recorded officially. He also spoke about how the app developed exclusively for the purpose of the program would be helpful to the sophomores. In case of any mishaps, all one has to do is post a complaint through the app and the issue would be resolved within 24 hours. He also stressed that the attending the Hall Assimilation is mandatory and one has to submit a written letter of absence to the hall president or the warden in case one misses out due to unavoidable circumstances.

Harsh Kumar Sharan, Deputy Contingent leader of InterIIT Cultural team, gave an introduction about cultural events and our records on the previous two Inter IIT competitions. He also gave an in short note on all the events and how one could get a position for themselves in the Inter IIT contingent. Harsh asked all sophomores present to work on their skills and on a lighter note, he added, “You can’t become captains in your second year because you suck at everything you do”.

The session was followed by the general secretaries, sports and games, who gave us an introduction to the sports culture in KGP. There was an after movie of past year InterIIT Sports Meet and performance of IIT KGP was discussed. They encouraged all sophomores to get their feet onto the field so that the thirteen-year draught would end (context: the last time we won at InterIIT sports meet was in 2005). Ways to make it to the contingent were discussed.

The final discussion about Tech events was more cheerful, thanks to our remarkable performance in Inter IIT Tech meets. All of the events that were conducted last year was discussed in detail. The selection procedure and preparation methods for the same were also discussed.

It is important to note that fair and transparent selections for most events were promised by the secretaries and assured the students that the notion that only people from certain societies could participate (which most people held) was false.

The next half of the program is scheduled at 6 PM, today at Kalidas.

The Scholars' Avenue shared a Page. The first quiz of this semester, named "Life, universe and the 4-4-2" concluded successfully with Baibhab Pattnaik and Kaniska Ghosh scoring the highest points in the campus(66) and thereby placing themselves among the top 20 teams overall. The quiz was an initiative by the Bombay Quiz Club (BQC) and as you might have guessed from the name, was based on football (FIFA World Cup, to be specific). For more updates on upcoming quizzes, follow https://www.facebook.com/iitkgp.quizclub/ (IIT KGP Quiz Club)

message:
Service staff of the Institute protested in front of the Hall Managment Centre. The protesters included mess workers and sanitary workers. They demanded that there be an increase in their wages.
"I know workers from other IITs who earn a lot more than we do. They make nearly 18000 a month whereas we make around 8000 a month" said a protester.
The protesters also threatened to stop offering services in case their demands are not met.
"We will discontinue our services from the 5th of August if our demands are not met. Everybody, including the sweeping staff, mess staff and even the cleaning staff that is responsible for hygiene in washrooms, will not show up for work, in protest. It is the student community that will perhaps face the maximum brunt of the protest. This could easily be avoided if the institute accepts our demands and pays us our rightful wages from the money it collects from students in the form of fees. Students from other IITs pay a similar fee but the workers get paid a lot more there" opined some protesters.
We hope that this issue is resolved before any inconveniences arise.

message:

We have compiled all the data of CG we had, and this is what we came up with.

The cutoffs for CS  soared up to 9.87 and every other department (except a few such as HSS and AE) showed a significant increase compared to that of last year. The dual degree course offered by Mechanical engineering department displayed an enormous raise of 0.5 points, almost coming close to the EC dual course’s cutoff from the previous year. 

Enough said, time for you to munch in all the data we have for you guys! Special thanks to every DepC candidate who helped in making this possible, congrats and a big shout out to you guys!

message:
Child Rights and You (CRY) IIT Kharagpur Volunteer Chapter
Volunteers at Child Rights and You (CRY) IIT Kharagpur Volunteer Chapter have been conducting child sexual abuse awareness cum workshops in schools under the project titled Baalrakshak. A total of 28 workshops, including separate ones for children and parents, have been conducted till now.
One of the workshops that they had conducted, (on 28th of April) has been covered and appreciated by national media as well.
Recently (on 20th of May) another workshop of a similar kind was conducted which was supported by the police administration. The police had promised support for all upcoming programs and also gave away chocolates to the children as a token of love.
Raising sexual awareness included teaching a large number of students the difference between good touch and bad touch. Students of class VI and VII were given self-defence classes too.
Incidents of late have iterated the need for proper sexual education in the country and projects like Baalrakshak will go a long way in serving that need. The Scholars' Avenue appreciates and congratulates CRY for such initiatives and wishes luck for all upcoming events.
Do check out
Child Rights and You (CRY) IIT Kharagpur Volunteer Chapter page for more details and pictures.

message:
Swarm Robotics IIT Kharagpur took part in DRDO's DRUSE 2018 (DRDO Robotics & Unmanned Systems Exposition) which was held in Pune from 23rd May to 25th May 2018 and won the First Runners Up position to win a cash prize of 1 Lac Rupees for further research and implementation. This was the culmination of the national level challenge which had over 1000 entries out of which 164 qualified for the Zonals on 28th March 2018 where they were crowned the runners-up in the 30 teams selected for the finals.
This team consists of UG Students from various departments and years who work together and had stayed back during the summers to prepare for this competition under the guidance of Prof. Somesh Kumar who is the Professor-in-charge for the project.

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the team for their strong showing and wishes them the best of luck for their future goals.

message:
20 people have been working with a team of lawyers headed by Dr. Menaka Guruswamy to file a writ petition against Section 377 of IPC that is an assault on the right to life with dignity of LGBTQ citizens of India. Their writ petition, on behalf of Pravritti, a group composed of over 350 IIT students and alumni who identify as LGBTQ citizens has been accepted for hearing at the Supreme Court before the CJI bench on expedited track[2]! Find the full press statement and details of the petition here: https://goo.gl/jkcB2i It is expected to be heard along with Navtej Singh Johar v Union of India upcoming in the July session of the court![1] More updates are upcoming especially on how you can get involved! Importantly, you can speak out in favour of LGBTQ rights and help us reach others to increase the force, base and reach of this cause.

Thank you to the team of lawyers, petitioners, LGBTQ supporters and allied friends who worked so hard to pull this through and are working to remove this colonial era blot from our constitution.

One of the members of this group, Keerthana, went live on NDTV 24x7 yesterday. The story can be found here: https://www.ndtv.com/india-news/iitians-go-to-top-court-demand-law-criminalising-gay-sex-be-scrapped-1851984

[1]: http://www.livelaw.in/want-know-8-cases-listed-hearing-constitution-bench-wednesday-jan-17-read-notice/
[2]: https://twitter.com/indialegalmedia/status/995895579778600960

Credits: Keerthana's original post: https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=2097393233622494&set=a.1083657641662730.1073741830.100000555121673&type=3

In an extremely unfortunate incident that folded out today,  Veeral Sheth, a third-year undergraduate student of the Department of Biotechnology and a boarder of the Rajendra Prasad (RP) Hall of Residence met with an accident today morning. After the end semester examinations,  he was spending time with his family in Valsad, Gujrat before leaving for his summer internship. He was riding his bike, which he adored when this happened and he succumbed to the injuries. 

Veeral served as the Core Team Head in the Spring Fest team, IIT Kharagpur. An avid follower of Chelsea football club and extremely fun-loving, Veeral was a gem one could have as a friend. 

This indeed is a great loss for the entire Kgp community. May God grant enough strength to his friends and family to bear this irreplaceable loss. We pray for the peace of the departed soul.

The Scholars' Avenue shared Alumni Cell, IIT Kharagpur's post. Kgp is a magic ride for all of us. It is a mixed bag of happiness, despair, and wonders. It has never failed to Stupefy all those who have set foot here and we hope this journey has been as fantastic as Alice’s adventures down the Rabbit Hole, as magical as Harry’s stay at Hogwarts and as adventurous as Bilbo’s quest for the ring that ‘rules them all’ for the entire graduating batch. With this journey slowly coming to its end for the Class of 2018, we’d like to fill up your treasure trove of memories with the best moments of your college life. So all the Harrys, Rons and Hermiones out there, dress up as anyone and anything you like on the 28th of April and grace the Bidhan Chowk with your presence from 4:30 PM onwards. Be a superhero from the Marvel Universe or a God from Mythology or simply a Holiday Armadillo. Anything or anyone. P.S.: Be ready to sway to the beats of the Class Song of 2018 ❤️

story: The Scholars' Avenue shared Alumni Cell, IIT Kharagpur's post.

message: The Scholars' Avenue shared Alumni Cell, IIT Kharagpur's post. Kgp is a magic ride for all of us. It is a mixed bag of happiness, despair, and wonders. It has never failed to Stupefy all those who have set foot here and we hope this journey has been as fantastic as Alice’s adventures down the Rabbit Hole, as magical as Harry’s stay at Hogwarts and as adventurous as Bilbo’s quest for the ring that ‘rules them all’ for the entire graduating batch. With this journey slowly coming to its end for the Class of 2018, we’d like to fill up your treasure trove of memories with the best moments of your college life. So all the Harrys, Rons and Hermiones out there, dress up as anyone and anything you like on the 28th of April and grace the Bidhan Chowk with your presence from 4:30 PM onwards. Be a superhero from the Marvel Universe or a God from Mythology or simply a Holiday Armadillo. Anything or anyone. P.S.: Be ready to sway to the beats of the Class Song of 2018 ❤️

A room in the top floor of D block in Radhakrishnan Hall caught fire and was severely damaged. The exact cause is not known but we are suspecting an appliance breakdown or a short circuit. Fortunately, no one was injured as the room was locked. 

We request all the students and members of the institute to stay careful and keep a check on their electrical appliances. Cases of short circuit are highly probable considering the current weather conditions, hence consider this as a gentle reminder and a warning issued in public interest.

It has come to our notice that the marking scheme in the Inter Hall Hardware Modeling event did not occur as per the standards set by the Tech GC rulebook.
According to the official rules, the median normalization must be applied to the total scores of each judge following which the now normalized scores of every judge are added to obtain the final standings. However, the General Secretary's calculations led to the normalization of each individual parameter of every judge, which then resulted in incorrect standings.

A few students have mailed Prof William K Mohanty requesting that he consider their case and have the renormalized scores as per the official rules decide the final results. We hope that the final ruling abides by the norms. 

With the gymkhana awards being scheduled to be presented today, even though logistical issues are posing a hindrance to a correction in the judgement, we wanted to let everyone be aware of the problem. We have also attached herewith the link to the spreadsheets with the original and renormalized scores. Stay tuned for further updates. 

The original scores can be found in this link:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/18OR3Jf0z1T6k27UE0xaegLWOZLggxHPcZSNqNXztTMY/edit?usp=gmail

The correctly renormalized scores can be found in this link:
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1ntRlMdEuGAf-LheZ7msLuI6E6XkpVxe6WqOcMXxH18k/edit?usp=gmail

Here's the list of the recipients of all the various awards over all the three genres of Technology, Social and Cultural, and Sports respectively, given to the current graduating batch of 2017-2018 (except Alumni Cup). 

Following the submissions of applications from everyone eligible for their respective awards, candidates are shortlisted according to their profiles and chosen for a suitable award. The shortlisted candidates will be presented with their awards at the Gymkhana Awards Ceremony to be held tomorrow, along with the other medals and cups offered for Inter IIT events and Inter Hall GC events.

We heartily congratulate every one of the awardees for their outstanding and selfless contribution in their respective spheres and making KGP a better place to live, learn and inspire.

message:
GC Social-Cultural 2017-18 || Final Events

WTGW:
Gold: Patel (-47)
Silver: RK (-21)
Bronze: Azad (100)

Dumb Charades:
Gold: Patel
Silver: RK (1 point difference from Gold)
Bronze: Azad

Thermocol and Clay Modelling
Gold: Azad
Silver: Patel, RK, LBS

With this, the GC, Social and Cultural comes to an end and the winners are RK Hall (913 points) followed very very closely by Patel Hall (888 points). 

The individual cup results are as follows:
Literary Cup: Patel Hall
Dramatics Cup: RK Hall
Fine Arts Cup: RK Hall
Entertainment Cup: Patel Hall 

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and hopes this same competitive spirit will carry forward into the next Inter-IIT Cultural Meet as well as the Inter-Hall GC.

Technology is in the name and a very essential part of our lives as KGPians and for this reason along with a multitude of others, the post of General Secretary Technology is very important for charting out a direction of where our public interests in this field are taking us.

This year, we have two candidates for the post who are running unopposed but we still consider the proposals of a candidate important and hence provide our views on what we think of each and every single proposal and the background work done for it.

Stay Tuned and Happy Voting!

Sports has always been a very crucial part of the KGP culture. With an ever-increasing sporting community and a similar trend being followed by the competition in the Inter-IIT Meets, new and fresh perspectives to improve the sporting culture in the campus are required which, not necessarily,  must be built on the foundations laid by the previous incumbents.

This election season has 4 competitors fighting it out for the post of General Secretary Sports and Games. Each one of them has come up with ideas on how they think they can improve the standard and quality of the KGP sporting culture and has laid down proposals along the same lines. We have done our part in breaking down their proposals into usable bits which collectively can put the voter in a better position to understand them and make the right choice in today's elections.

Presenting to you our critique of the G.Sec- Sports and Games 2018-19. 

Stay tuned for more and Happy voting!

https://web.scholarsavenue.org/critique-general-secretary-sports-2018-19-38b4387dd321

It's just a few minutes away from D-Day, the day when the student community of KGP gets to exercise its democratic power and instate new leaders in positions of responsibilities meant to push forward agendas and proposals directed towards a better KGP. The SOP's have concluded, as always with enough entertainment to last for more than just a heartbeat, but on a serious note, the SOP's have provided every candidate with a platform to outline their proposals for improving some aspect of the campus and defending them to their fiercest extent, in front of the entire KGP community. 

As always, it isn't easy to gauge the proposals put forward by the candidates at first glance and given that the proposals should be undoubtedly taken into account for influencing a voter's mind, we at The Scholars' Avenue have done some of the work of simplifying the proposals and breaking it down into chunks easy enough for everyone to understand. 

We present to you the first of our critique series for this election season - General Secretary Social and Cultural 2018-19. We will come out with the others soon enough. Stay tuned and Happy voting!

https://web.scholarsavenue.org/critique-general-secretary-social-and-cultural-2018-19-1480c5471adc

In an attempt to build indigenous technologies for commercial usage our institute is working on developing an ecosystem of budding technical entrepreneurs. One such project on Rain and Fog removal from Video Sequences has been taken up by Prof. Sudipta Mukhopadhyay and his team. Patents have been filed in US, Europe and South Korea. Basic application has been shown to work and is being approached by the world top leaders in Defence and Transportation. To scale up the work and improve the commercial viability of the product interns are being hired to work in the following related fields. Interested and enthusiastic students are invited to fill in the google form below. They will be invited to the recruitment drive soon.

https://goo.gl/forms/Dn5ilhGnEbnmse2g2

Interns required in the following domains : Product Development, Android Programming, CUDA C, Image Processing, Machine Learning

Eligibility : Anyone interested is invited
Time Period : Summers 2018 and beyond
Stipend : Will be provided on the basis of alloted work

For any queries you can contact Professor Sudipta Mukhopadhyay, Department of E&ECE, IIT Kharagpur.

message:
Nobody has any doubts over how convenient a bicycle is on the campus (no wonder we have so many psyclepaths* on the campus). Nevertheless, cycles have a reputation for being a pain in the neck. Cyclogists* at The Scholars' Avenue, after having done extensive research, present you, "The Anatomy of a KGP Bicycle". We request bikeaholics* to not get offended.

*psyclepaths = people who love cycles.
*bikeaholic = same as above.
*Cyclogists, ok, at this point, it is clear that we are just showing off our skill at pun making.

Nobody has any doubts over how convenient a bicycle is on the campus (no wonder we have so many psyclepaths* on the campus). Nevertheless, cycles have a reputation for being a pain in the neck. Cyclogists* at The Scholars' Avenue, after having done extensive research, present you, "The Anatomy of a KGP Bicycle". We request bikeaholics* to not get offended.

*psyclepaths = people who love cycles.
*bikeaholic = same as above.
*Cyclogists, ok, at this point, it is clear that we are just showing off our skill at pun making.

Final Day | Quiz Week
Sci-Tech and Pop-culture Quiz

The last day of the quiz week had the least number of attendants, so much so that the number of teams in the finals had to be lowered down to 7 and 5 to maintain competitiveness. The Quizzes, however, maintained their standards and the questions were spread across the board in both the quizzes.

Sci-Tech Quiz Results: 
First: Piyush Kedia, Kaniska Ghosh, Rishiraj Bose (225)
Second: Mayank Roy, Rupam Kumar Dubey, Adithya Srikanth (220)
Third: Girish Suranje, Harsha Vattem, Robin Babu P (185)

Pop-Culture Quiz Results:
First: Amit Kumar Ram, Girish Suranje, Kaustav Mandal (188)
Second: Baibhab Pattnaik, Sangeeta Roy, Lakshay Singhal (177)
Third: Abhimanyu Bharade, Prachurjya Biswas, Kaniska Ghosh (156)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club for a successful quiz week.

Since we didn't have photos for the sessions, the quiz set in the pop-culture quiz run by Hemansh and Mayank Roy is being shared instead. :)

General Quiz and Biz Quiz | Quiz Week Day 5

Day 5 saw a very busy day with quizzes after quizzes going on at Vikramshila. General Quiz started early in the afternoon with people gathering being treated with a dose of everything in the world. After that, the Biz Quiz took place in the evening and saw a very topsy-turvy finale with the final spots getting chosen in the final few questions.

Results:
General Quiz:
First: Amit Kumar Ram, Agnimitra Anand, Pranav Joshi (260)
Second: Piyush Kedia, Rupam Kumar Dubey, Vaibhav Krishna (210)
Third: Kaustav Mandal, Kaniska Ghosh + 1 (205)

Biz Quiz:
First: Piyush Kedia, Kaustav Mandal, Anmol Joshi (270)
Second: Sourav Chirania, Harsha Vattem, Siddhant Ladha (240)
Third: Amit Kumar Ram, Anurag Mondal, Shubhra Agrawal (230)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates all the winners and wishes IIT KGP Quiz Club best of luck for the last day of the Quiz Week tomorrow.

MELA Quiz | Quiz Week Day 4

Day 4 saw a lot of the MELA enthusiasts in the campus turn up for the quiz which turned out to be a very entertaining, exciting and close affair right down till the last question when the podium was finally decided.
This time around, all the participants who qualified from the prelims stayed back to sit for the finals and made the event a success.

First: Agnimitra Anand, Kaniska Ghosh, Mayank Roy
Second: R. Srihari, Anurag Kar, Prachurjya Biswas
Third: Mohit Tulsyan, Nikhil Nayan Jha, Varun PD

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and the QMs on an exciting quiz and wishes IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club the best of luck for the four quizzes to be held in the next two days.

Women's Quiz | Quiz Week Day 3

Day 3, a veritable first for KGP quizzing in many ways saw a women-only quiz being conducted with 25 participants, which, compared to the norm of 2-3 women in regular quizzes was a huge improvement. It continued the trend of first-timers leaving right after prelims without waiting for the results for yet another day in a row where the third member of the (later on)first place team left, assuming she wouldn't qualify. Considering that almost all of the participants being first-time quizzers, the scores received in the prelims and finals results were very competitive.
The aim of the event had been to try and introduce women to the sport and the response, especially in the finals from teams was very positive, with blocks and enthusiastic hint requests and clarifications going around on questions. The finals boiled down to a tie-breaker for third place and after three further tie-breaker questions which couldn't break the tie, the third place remained tied till the end in the final result.
Prof. Seema Singh of the HSS department also graced the event with her presence and stayed almost till the end of the quiz.

First: Sangeeta Roy, Shubhra Agrawal (225)
Second: Ayushi Mrigen, Nikita Gautam, Kavana Rao (135)
Third: Shubhi Jain, Abhigna Revuru, Nayan Kubade (130) and
Pankhuri Saxena, Samruddhi Pataskar and Pankhudi Jain (130)
Fourth: (125)
Fifth: (120)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and hopes that this helps somewhat bridge the gender disparity in quizzing in the campus and further wishes IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club best of luck for the future quizzes in this event.
story: The Scholars' Avenue added 4 new photos — with Bindu Sancheti and Shweta Jaiswal.

message:
India Quiz | Quiz Week: Day 2

Day 2 in the Intra-KGP Quiz Week saw an even higher participation from the KGP population, with similar scenes occurring with first timers as day one. Another prelims participant had to miss out because of low self-confidence about his own talent because he left for his hall without leaving any contact info.
Both the prelims and finals were highly entertaining, with all the three podium places getting cleared out in the final three questions of the quiz with all the other teams chasing just 5-15 points behind.
The point of female participation came up again today, but this time, there was some participation from the female populace and one of them even making it to the finals.

First: Harsh Agarwal, Pinaki Mishra, Sourav Kundu (180)
Second: Sourav Chirania, Baibhab Pattnaik, Kaniska Ghosh (150)
Third: Satyam Agarwal, Pratik Gokul Zaware, Shreyans Sadangi (145)
Fourth, Fifth, Sixth: (140)
 
The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and wishes IIT Kharagpur Quiz Club all the best for today's Women Only Quiz.
story: The Scholars' Avenue added 2 new photos.

And I'll tell you all about it when I see you again
We've come a long way from where we began
Oh I'll tell you all about it when I see you again
When I see you again ♬
We present you the Graphduation Theory where we show you, pictorially, the emotions one goes through when she/he gets set to graduate. Tag your graduating friends to let them know that ♫ It's gon' be a long day...♬

Sports Quiz | Quiz Week : Day 1

Today saw the participation of close to 70 people for the prelims and we saw the greatest fear of most non-quizzers coming up in action and tackled head-on.
Two people out of the 24 finalists scored higher than Quiz Club regulars and yet, because they thought they hadn't done well enough, left without even waiting for the results. One of them didn't submit their contact details so we couldn't even reach them to let them know and hence had to take the next highest scorer present. We later got to know that there were two-three people who didn't want to see if they could qualify and didn't submit their answer sheet for checking, where it turned out that they would've actually qualified for the finals. The team that won actually had a member like that, who after giving up, decided to go to his room, from where he had to be called to come back for the finals and eventually won. The finals itself was a cliffhanger with the podium places getting decided in the last two questions of the quiz.

Furthermore, there were no women in attendance. An event, that has no barriers to entry, and no prerequisites for taking part, as well as cash prizes and refreshments where non-regulars to QC sessions turned up and performed very well had an entire section of our campus population giving it a miss in participation definitely speaks volumes about this. We invite discussion regarding this in the comments section, and more than discussion, ideas to improve this situation, considering that Quiz Club has brought laurels for the institute in multiple places throughout the past years and their current Quiz Week initiative is an attempt to lure in people who don't consider themselves knowledgeable enough.

Final Results:

First: B. Pattnaik, Bhart Singh, Sougata Paul (135)
Second: Agnimitra Anand, Piyush Kedia, Hemansh Kashyap (120)
Third: Amit Kumar Ram, Rajat Jain, Kaushal Vadera (118)
Fourth Place: (115)

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates the winners and wishes Quiz Club all the best for the rest of the quizzes to be held as part of Quiz Week.

message: The Scholars' Avenue shared Business Club, IIT Kharagpur's post. Greetings! ZS associates in collaboration with Business Club brings to you an open house session -“Brown Bag on the Art and Science of Problem-Solving”. It will focus on understanding the most effective approaches of solving a case study. This session will also act as an introduction to the case study competition to be organized by ZS, winners of which will get Pre-Placement Interview (PPI) offers from ZS! What to wait for? Embark on the journey of honing your skills and begin your expedition into the fascinating world of consulting that might just hold your future. We have exciting goodies and refreshments that await your presence. This session is exclusively for pre-final year students. Since limited number of seats are available, register at: https://tinyurl.com/y989quod 7 PM, 6th March | V4 For any queries please contact: Puneet: 9783611967 Aman: 7430011888

message:
Heartiest congratulations to Mr. Shreshth Khare and Mr. Sanskar Rawat, third-year undergraduates of the Department of Chemical Engineering for winning the 8th edition of EXL Excellence Quotient (EQ) data case challenge. The competition is held across 20 top engineering institutes including 8 IITs and 7 NITs. A total of 680 teams registered for the competition and after two stages of submissions, top 6 teams were invited to present their case in the National Finals at EXL Head Office, Gurgaon. Ms. Anjali Bharti and  Mr. Anshul Gupta from IIT Kharagpur working under the Team title "Panacea "  also secured their position in the National finals.

The winning team, Team Insidious from IIT Kharagpur received a cash prize of Rs. 1 Lakh along with certificates and winning trophy. Pre-placement interview offer was extended to all the 6 teams who made it to the National Finals.

Ankur Mehta, a fourth-year B.Tech student from Department of Chemical Engineering, IIT Kharagpur has won the Best Oral Presentation Award at the International Conference on Clean and Green Energy(ICCGE) held in Paris, France on February 7-9, 2018 for his presentation titled "Kinetics of delignification and Enzymatic Hydrolysis of non-food lignocellulose for Cellulosic Biofuel Production". 

The Scholars' Avenue congratulates him and wishes him all the best for the future. It is great to see the growing culture of research among undergraduate students and we hope to see many more of such accomplishments.

message:
Safety Analytics and Virtual Reality lab in the Department of Industrial and Systems Engineering invited The Scholars' Avenue to showcase their work and projects. Established in May 2016 under the mentorship of the Prof Partha P Chakrabarti, Director IIT Kharagpur, and under the charge of Prof Jhareswar Maiti, Head of Department, Industrial and Systems Engineering, the SAVR Lab has state of the art facilities to carry out research in Virtual Reality. The lab is equipped with the essential tools such as 3D laser scanners, military-grade head-mounted displays, oculus rifts, data gloves, powerful computers, projectors etc. The lab has been sponsored by the Government of India under the Uchhatar Avishkar Yojana (UAY) to promote Virtual Reality research.
 
Their “hero project”, for all the Elon Musk fans out there, is a Virtual Reality [VR] simulation of SpaceX’s Star-man created by Prateek Srivastava [Third-year undergraduate, Department of Ocean Engineering and Naval Architecture]. 
 
A team of 10 students including Manorama Jha[research scholar] and Siddharth Jindal [Third-year undergraduate, Department of Mathematics and Computing]  led by Prateek and mentored by Mr. Anirban Santara [PhD scholar and a 2015 B.Tech graduate, Department of Electronics and Electrical Communications Engineering], who is popular in the Artificial Intelligence community of Kharagpur, are working on the Virtual KGP project, a complete open-source VR simulation of the campus which they hope will help in initiating other projects for development of different VR applications. To aid the completion of the project they intend to organize various hackathons where students will be awarded for adding intricate details. They aim to collaborate with the Urban Planning Department of IIT Kharagpur in making an app which will help regional planners visualize their designs. With Autonomous Ground Vehicle, IIT Kharagpur they plan to create a highly accurate and photorealistic simulation of an autonomous car through an open sourced project- the first of its kind in the world.
 
The lab has also taken up a project sponsored by Tata Steel to simulate the Electric Overhead Travelling [EOT] Crane in the hope of reducing industrial accidents and improving safety standards. Recognising the scope for research in Virtual Reality in various sectors like education, industry, and entertainment, they are encouraging Virtual Reality research in the campus and are inviting B.Tech and M.Tech students to take up projects in their lab. 
 
The lab invites students to come in small groups to catch a glimpse of their SpaceX's Star-man simulation.
story: The Scholars' Avenue added 33 new photos — with Manorama Jha and 5 others.

message:
The first weekend of this month witnessed an influx of eminent personalities in the fields of business and entrepreneurial ventures thanks to the Global Entrepreneurship Summit organised by Entrepreneurship Cell, IIT Kharagpur. Among them, Mr.Gulzar Azad was one of the guest speakers invited to share his experiences. We thank them for giving us a chance to interact with him.

Mr. Azad is the present connectivity head of Google India. One look at his profile will speak of his rich experience of working in different kinds of environments and his steady rise. We were glad to have an exciting chat with him on various topics, mainly his iconic RailWire Project, the fruits of which can be seen in the form of free wifi not only here at the Kharagpur Railway Station but all over the country and his experience of working with Google with respect to the entrepreneurial and networking opportunities it opened up for him. He had a lot of interesting things to say on this front and much more.

Check out the link below to share some of his thoughts on several topics ranging from intrepreneurship, free Wi-Fi to how Google shaped him into what he is today.

 https://youtu.be/69NctEpzNUI

He had a lot of interesting things to say on this front and much more.

Check out the link below to share some of his thoughts on several topics ranging from intrepreneurship, free Wi-Fi to how Google shaped him into what he is today.

 https://youtu.be/69NctEpzNUI

"People often say that motivation doesn't last. Well, neither does bathing. That's why we recommend it daily."
- Zig Ziglar
Starting the Graph Theory for this semester with one of the most distinctive traits of our breed of engineers, a tradition rooted in the annals of history and followed ardently even today. May there be a time when the art of bathing, or not rather, becomes your badge of honour . Till then here's a something you can refer to. 
Does it represent you? Let us know what you think in the comments.

message:
After series of tests at the CIC Lab, the Technology Transfer Group in association with the Sponsored Research and Industry Consultancy (SRIC) has officially launched the Undergraduate Research Portal today at the Netaji Auditorium. Prof.  S K Barai (Dean UGS) and Prof. Sriman Bhattacharya (Deputy Director) were present there along with few other Professors who gave an insight to the research fields and enumerated the research groups developed at IIT Kharagpur. The portal aims at promoting research among Undergrads, who can now apply for projects to work during their summer/ winter vacations. There was a demonstration in which a professor, Dumbledore floats a project topic of research, "The Sorting Hat Algorithm." Harry and Draco, the students, apply by filling the form through their student accounts in the portal and uploading a CV. Based on the applications, Draco gets rejected, and Harry selected who then starts to work on the project.
This initiative could tailor young minds towards research, thus bringing about a much-needed evolution in the research culture at IIT KGP.
